h3. Issue Summary

Customer has logged an issue as a support ticket stating that when entering multiple lines of formatting in the "description" field within the import tool - all the text is flattened on one line

They have suggested the following to remedy the situation:
(1) handle the description field either verbatim or as markdown
(2) prevent use of newlines in the description field as this creates the misleading impression that they will appear in the output
h3. Steps to Reproduce
Use "Import repository" (or "Create repository")
Expand "Advanced settings"
Enter the following in "Description" (including newlines):
-----
This is a description

The text entry box supports newlines.
- so we'll enter a note
- and another note
-----

Once repository is created, view the repository. The text in "description" appears at the top below the repository name.
h3. Expected Results

- Description is either rendered verbatim or parsed as Markdown
h3. Actual Results

- Description is flattened and appears all on a single line.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Import - Advanced settings - "description" accepts formatting but gets flattened when rendered

fields.description:
There is no option for customers to set primary Jira instance while they have multiple Jira instances linked to their single BitBucket cloud. 

In the above scenario, if they have same project names on both Jira instances, the Bitbucket cloud issues Jira key the URL of the Jira instance which was registered first with the Bitbucket cloud account.

Eg: Let's say customer is having two Jira instances [https://one/jira] and [https://two/jira.|https://two/jira]

Customer will connect these two instances to their Bitbucket cloud account but in the order of 1) [https://one/jira]  and 2) [https://two/jira.|https://two/jira]

If customer creates project with key "PROJ" in both the instances and issues the Jira key eg: "PROJ-1" to a Bitbucket commit, the Bitbucket will assign URL of Jira instance [https://one/jira,|https://one/jira], which was registered first.

If customer wants the Jira keys to be linked with second Jira instance [https://two/jira.|https://two/jira] , then customer had to disconnect the first Jira instance [https://one/jira.|https://one/jira]

It will be a good option to let customers group their Jira instances and mark one of them as primary. by doing this customers will be aware of the Jira URL linked to their issued keys.
fields.summary: No option for customers to set primary Jira instance while they have multiple Jira instances linked to their single Bitbucket cloud

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When you have a local repo with a certain branch name, e.g. 'master' and you try to push it to BBC repo that was created with a different main branch name, e.g. 'main', the instructions will lead to an error.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have a local repository. Note the name of the branch you will want to push to BBC.
 # Create a new repo on BBC with no files added and with a default main branch different from what you have in your local repo from step 1.  
 ## No README
 ## No git ignore file
 # Follow the instructions from the BBC UI page after you created the repo in step 2.

h3. Expected Results

Local repo will be pushed to BBC successfully and the BBC branch name will be used that was configured during the BBC repo creation as the default branch name.
h3. Actual Results

The below error will be received:
{noformat}
error: src refspec master does not match any
error: failed to push some refs to <...> {noformat}
h3. Workaround
h4. Option 1:

Step 1: Switch to your repository's directory
 {{cd /path/to/your/repo}}
Step 2: Rename your local branch name to match your remote default branch name
 {{git branch -m <source branch name> <destination branch name>}}
Step 3: Connect your existing repository to Bitbucket
 {{git remote add origin git@bitbucket.org:<your remote>.git}}
{{git push -u origin <destination branch name>}}
h4. Option 2:

Step 1: Switch to your repository's directory
 {{cd /path/to/your/repo}}
Step 2: Connect your existing repository to Bitbucket
 {{git remote add origin git@bitbucket.org:<your remote>.git}}
{{git push -u origin <source branch name>:<destination branch name>}}
 
where <source branch name> is the branch name used in the local repo and <destination branch name> is the BBC repo branch name. Please note there is another issue in that if you created BBC repo's default branch name as "branchA" but in the above command you use "branchB" as your <destination branch name>, "branchB" will be used.
fields.summary: Following instructions for pushing local repo to an empty BBC repo fails when branch names don't match

fields.description:
It seems that there are no provider packages to manage Bitbucket Cloud resources via Pulumi.  Pulumi has a Terraform bridge, but there is also no official provider available for Terraform that could be used.

With the advance of microservice architectures there is often an increasing number of repositories and pipelines to manage.  It would be great if these resources could be provisioned in an automated, reproducable, and configurable way.  For example:
 * project
 * workspace variable
 * repository
 * repo variables 
 * deployment
 * deployment variable
 * webhook
 * permissions

Questions:
 # Are there any plans at Atlassian to publish native Pulumi provider packages for Bitbucket Cloud resources?
 # If not, are there any plans to publish an official Terraform provider?  The terraform-bridge is probably not the best solution for Pulumi users, but still better than nothing.
fields.summary: Native Pulumi provider package for managing Bitbucket Cloud resources

So I had to review a huge PR today and I couldn't see all the files from top to bottom and I though maybe there is a shortcut to navigate between files. Nope. All I can do is show hide left and right sidebar. 
This appear at the end of the first file : 
To view another file, use the file tree in the right sidebar or navigation buttons in the header.

Ok but can I use the navigation without a mouse ? What is annoying in this context is that there isn't a file view... So you must navigate from previous/next file until you get the right file. With 131 files changed, it's inefficient navigating in all those files... I can't imagine what reviewing a PR double that size could be... 

Anyway, to summaries in bullet point :
 * Navigating through keyboard in Pull Request would help a lot.
 ** Next/Previous file.
 ** Next/Previous hunk.
 ** Collapse/Display current hunk.
 ** Navigate lines.
 ** Add comment for the line/files.
 * Having a file explorer as sidebar would help review/navigate to a specific file when needed.

I have use Azure DevOps for the past 3 years. I can said that navigating in Bitbucket is not as easy nor intuitive. Maybe I'm not used to the workflow, but I definitely think those 2 bullets points are a must have that is missing.
fields.summary: Navigating in Pull Request should be easier. Keyboard shortcut and File view.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

 

Currently, when the repository has integration with an issue tracker and the *Require issue keys in commit messages* option is enabled, it´s not possible to create a pipeline using the Bitbucket UI's Pipeline section.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Link a Bitbucket repository, that has no pipeline configured, to an issue tracker (Jira in this example) **
 # Under *Repository Settings > Workflows > Links*, enable the option *Require issue keys in commit messages*
 # Go to the repository's Pipeline section and create a new pipeline using any of the templates
 # Try to commit the pipeline YAML file, and it will fail with the message: _"Committing file was unsuccessful. You may have restricted write access to the branch."_**

 

This happened because the default commit message of the YAML file created when you first commit your pipeline through the UI is "Initial Bitbucket Pipelines configuration". This message cannot be changed, and since it has no *Issue Key*, Bitbucket is not allowing the commit, and showing a generic access issue message.
h3. Expected Results

The correct error message is shown, stating the commit failed because of a missing issue key, and allow commit message to be edited.
h3. Actual Results

The default commit message cannot be changed and a generic error message about branch write permissions was showed.
h3. Workaround

Manually create the *bitbucket-pipelines.yml* file and push it to the repository with a commit message containing an issue Key.
fields.summary: Unable to create a pipeline using the UI when repository requires issue key

fields.description:
Pipelines Runners builds pull certain public images from DockerHub to be able to run themselves, such as "sox/atlassian/bitbucket-pipelines-dvcs-tools". 

This is necessary for Runners to be executed in the first place, regardless if your actual build image is hosted on a private registry. This causes a problem though, as [DockerHub will rate-limit users|https://www.docker.com/increase-rate-limits] after 200 authenticated requests, effectively causing Pipelines to have a hard cap of 200 builds every 6 hours, unless the user has a paid DockerHub account.

This feature request is to provide the ability for users to fetch the Runners-required images from their private registries, so that they won't get rate-limited by DockerHub.
fields.summary: Ability to pull images that Pipelines Runners depend on from private registries

fields.description:
A useful feature would to be able to view a git diff on changed files since a particular commit.

For example, when we have code reviews of a pull request, and inevitably create tasks to fix the code, it would be helpful to be able to see only the changes from the commit we reviewed instead of the entire pull request changes.

If you want to get fancy, you could also select an end commit to view the diff, with default being the current HEAD.

Currently my solution is to open each commit separately and review the changes in order of commit, but having a single view to show the changes in that range would be ideal.

Thank you and hope to see this kind of functionally in the future :).

Keep up the good work!
fields.summary: Ability to view a git diff since a commit

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When merging a pull request through the UI, the merge may appear to fail with a "Something went wrong" error. However, the merge will have been made in the repository even though the pull request remains open.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Merge a pull request with "Close source branch" checked in the merge dialog

This behavior is intermittent and rare, so it will be difficult to reproduce consistently.
h3. Expected Results

The pull request is marked merged, the source branch is merged into the destination branch, and the source branch is closed.
h3. Actual Results

The source branch is merged into the destination branch, but is not closed, and the pull request is not marked as merged.
h3. Workaround

Pushing or merging an additional commit into either the source or destination branch of the pull request should cause Bitbucket to detect the merge and update the pull request.
fields.summary: Merging pull request shows error and PR doesn't close but the merge succeeded

h3. Issue Summary
When you perform a pull request on a repository, you will receive an e-mail even if you aren't watching the repository in *Personal Settings > Notification Settings*
I have had a customer comment that this is bordering on spam, he needs to un-watch the pull request to stop receiving notification emails on it despite being unsubscribed from all objects in his repository. As soon as he performs another pull request, he is again notified in his inbox and must un-watch that pull request. He is the only person in his workspace, therefore he doesn't need these emails to be sent when he is the one performing all the pull requests.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Un-watch the repository you are creating a pull request for in *Personal Settings > Notification Settings*
 # Perform a pull request on that repository and merge, notification email is still received

h3. Expected Results
Repository is unsubscribed, therefore no email notification is sent

h3. Actual Results
Repository is unsubscribed, email notification is still sent

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Pull request sends notification even if repository/object is not watched

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In branch permissions, you have merge checks with the option "Require one successful build and no failed builds.

If you have at least 2 builds on the latest commit and one of it is in progress, the "In Progress" build is not counted as a failed build or waited out for the result to pass the merge checks.

As long as merge check condition is met, 1 successful and no "Failed" builds (ignoring the build "In Progress), the merge will be allowed to go through.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have Merge Checks enabled on a repository with the condition "Require one successful build and no failed builds"
 ** Enable "Prevent merge if merge conditions aren't met".
 # In the latest commit, keep 1 build as successful and another as "In Progress"
 # Attempt to perform the merge and the merge will be allowed.

If the second build fails (after the merge is completed), it will show as the merge conditions is not met
h3. Expected Results

Merge is not allowed to go through until the "In Progress" builds have completed
h3. Actual Results

Since "In Progress" builds isn't counted against the merge checks, the PR is allowed to merge as long as the conditions are met.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Merge Checks allows PR to merge even when it has Build Status "In Progress"

Possible causes: Let's Encrypt's DST Root CA X3 has expired and now it's using their own ISRG Root X1 root certificate, but this new root certificate is not supported on older devices/images, which doesn't have the latest ca-certificates package.
Source: https://letsencrypt.org/docs/dst-root-ca-x3-expiration-september-2021/

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 Use Atlassian/default-image:2 and the pipelines fail with "certificate verification failed " while accessing few external API endpoints

h3. Expected Results
To fetch the data

h3. Actual Results
 "curl: (60) server certificate verification failed."


h3. Workaround
Try to upgrade the OpenSSL to higher than 1.1.0 or use an image that already contains the latest OpenSSL/ca-certificates package
fields.summary: Bitbucket pipelines failing with 'Invalid certificate error'

fields.description:
h3. Update: This issue is fixed

Bitbucket Cloud now supports {{rsa-sha2-256}} and {{rsa-sha2-512}} algorithms. The OpenSSH 8.8 client will function without the need for a workaround.

The team deployed a fix on Tuesday, Oct 19. After monitoring for two days, this ticket was closed because we are confident that the OpenSSH 8.8 incompatibility has been resolved.
----
h3. Issue Summary

The latest release of OpenSSH — version 8.8, released on September 26th — introduced a configuration change that prevents that client from connecting to Bitbucket Cloud over SSH. Bitbucket engineers are actively addressing this, and there are workarounds available in the meantime.

See the [Community post|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-articles/OpenSSH-8-8-client-incompatibility-and-workaround/ba-p/1826047] for more details.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Connect to bitbucket.org using OpenSSH >= 8.8.
h3. Expected Results

SSH client connects to Bitbucket.
h3. Actual Results

SSH connection fails with the following error message:

{{Unable to negotiate with <ip address> port 22: no matching host key type found. Their offer: ssh-rsa,ssh-dss}}
h3. Workaround

If you are receiving the warning above, there are two options: updating your SSH config locally, or switching from SSH to HTTPS.
h4. Update local SSH configuration

You can continue to use SSH by adding the lines below into the {{Host bitbucket.org}} section of your SSH configuration:

{{Host bitbucket.org}}
 {{   HostkeyAlgorithms +ssh-rsa}}
 {{   PubkeyAcceptedAlgorithms +ssh-rsa}} 

On Unix-like systems, this configuration is located at {{$HOME/.ssh/config}} or {{/etc/ssh/ssh_config}}.

On Windows systems, this configuration is located at {{%USERPROFILE%\.ssh\config}} or {{%PROGRAMFILES%\Git\etc\ssh\ssh_config}}.
h4. Use HTTPS instead of SSH

HTTPS connections to Bitbucket Cloud are unaffected by changes to the OpenSSH client. Therefore, you can avoid this issue by updating your git client to use HTTPS instead of SSH to talk to Bitbucket Cloud by following the instructions on [this page|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/change-the-remote-url-to-your-repository/]. Switching to HTTPS will require using a different authentication mechanism. We recommend using an [app password|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/app-passwords/] for automated git clients such as build machines or if you have two-factor authentication enabled.

To remove this workaround in the future, follow [the same instructions|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/change-the-remote-url-to-your-repository/] to change your remote URL back to the SSH URL.
fields.summary: OpenSSH 8.8 client incompatibility and workaround

fields.description:
This ticket follows the tickets https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-13737 and https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-18771.

 

Bitbucket has made a good progress so far in supporting for CI/CD. It would have been better if Bitbucket can support for multiple pre-defined values for variables in custom pipelines. And then display them in a dropdown where the users can select a value from.

 

Having to type values for the variable in a input box is trouble and error-prone. The facility to select a value from a dropdown is the best. The ideal use case would be as below.

 

In bitbucket-pipelines.yml

 
{code:java}
pipelines:
  custom:
    testing:
      - variables:
          - name: LOCALE
            values:
              - "en"
              - "cs"
           - name: TENANT
             values:
              - "tenant1_name"
              - "tenant2_name"
              - "tenant3_name"{code}
 

In order to mitigate this issue with the current Bitbucket facilities as of now, I have to write 6 custom pipelines (2 locales x 3 tenants), repeating the same pipeline code but, using different values for the 2 env variables.

 

In bitbucket-pipelines.yml
{code:java}
pipelines:
  custom:
    testing-tenant1_name-en:
      - step:
          name: "Deploy tenant1_name to testing in en"
          deployment: test
          script:
            - pipe: atlassian/ssh-run:0.3.1
              variables:
                SSH_USER: "$SSH_USER"
                SERVER: "$SERVER"
                MODE: 'script'
                COMMAND: 'deploy.sh'
                ENV_VARS: >-
                  TENANT="tenant1_name"
                  LOCALE="en"

    testing-tenant1_name-cs:
      - step:
          name: "Deploy tenant1_name to testing in cs"
          deployment: test
          script:
            - pipe: atlassian/ssh-run:0.3.1
              variables:
                SSH_USER: "$SSH_USER"
                SERVER: "$SERVER"
                MODE: 'script'
                COMMAND: 'deploy.sh'
                ENV_VARS: >-
                  TENANT="tenant1_name"
                  LOCALE="cs"{code}
fields.summary: Support multiple values in a dropdown for custom pipeline variables

fields.description:
Pipelines team did a great job releasing self-hosted pipeline runners, and it is time to go further and make them even better =)

 

Currently, runners in my projects spend way too much time uploading/downloading caches and intermediate artifacts. It can take up to 90% for fast jobs like linters, and is complete waste of time, since the cache has already been downloaded in previous step. Because of that I cannot split my jobs to smaller ones - if I do so, it will end with pipelines taking more time to finish, which is inapropriate. Every cache defined adds a time to upload/download and compress/uncompress (my projects currently have 8 caches at most, but this number will soon grow).



I suggest a local cache and artifacts for self-hosted runners. In case they are all running at the same machine (which is definitely doable for most of the projects), it will decrease pipelines duration, because no unnecessary network traffic will occur.

 

You can also get some inspiration from Gitlab CI cache system =)
fields.summary: Local cache/artifacts for Self-hosted Pipelines Runner

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

It's possible to create a public repository under a private project using the API.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Make sure the projects in your workspace are private
 * Use the following request to create a repository under this workspace: 

{code:java}
curl -X POST -u username:AppPassword -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"scm": "git", "project": {"key": "{inform_the_project_key_here}" }}' https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/{workspacename}/{repository_name}{code}
 * Don't specify if the repository is public or private and don't inform the project key 

h3. Expected Results
 * You should receive a rejected request saying that you can't create a public repository in a private project.

h3. Actual Results
 * A public repository will be created under a private project
 * You will not be able to delete this repository through the UI
 * You may not be able to change the repository to private using the UI due to this other bug: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BCLOUD-21027 

h3. Workaround
 * You can update the repo via a PUT request:
{code:java}
curl -X PUT -u username:AppPassword -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"is_private": true}' https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/{workspace_name}/{repository_name}{code}

 * If you specify the project key and it's a private project, you will receive an error message saying that "Private projects cannot contain public repositories"
fields.summary: It's possible to create a public repository under a private project using the API

h3. Issue Summary

When you create a private fork from a parent repo, commit some work into the fork and then create a PR from Fork to Parent repo. The owner of the parent repo will not be able to Edit that PR to add reviewers or edit PR description. 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a fork from a private repo
 # do some work
 # Create a PR from Fork to Parent repo
 # owner of the Destination repo will not be able to: edit Description, Edit PR or add reviewers

h3. Expected Results

!Screen Shot 2021-09-24 at 4.41.45 PM.png!

Users can click on "accept the invitation" again post sign-up or the admin can resend the invitation.

h3. Issue Summary

Pull request diffs can sometimes time out or it load slowly. This affects both the UI and the API. The user will see 500, 502, 504 or 555 errors.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

This can only be reproduced under certain specific circumstances, this will not happen on all pull request diffs. Sometimes the same pull request may experience this issue intermittently and sometimes load successfully.
h3. Expected Results

No timeouts or errors on pull request diffs.
h3. Actual Results

Timeouts or slow responses. The user will see 500, 502, 504 or 555 errors.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior but there are some workflow changes that can alleviate the problem to some extent:
 * Retry. It may be intermittent for the pull request (diff) in question
 * Inspect the diff locally and if you see conflicts, resolve them. Sometimes pull requests fail or time out because there are conflicts in the diff.
 * Ensure your pull request diff is not exceeding the documented limits: [https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/limits-for-viewing-content-and-diffs/]
fields.summary: Pull request diff times out or loads slowly

h3. Issue Summary
Viewing the code insight report in a pull request for more than 3 reports returns an error to upgrade plan for Paid Workspace
 !Screenshot 2021-09-23 at 3.42.29 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Use pay Workspace Standart or Premium
# Create a PR
# Create a dummy test report following our guide [here|https://support.atlassian.com/bitbucket-cloud/docs/code-insights/#hardBreak]
# Create 4 or more reports
# Open the Pull Request from the dashboard

(!) It's important not to refresh the page to reproduce this issue as refreshing it fix the issue.

h3. Expected Results
* The test results show all the reports accordingly

h3. Actual Results
* The test results don't show more than 3 reports and ask customers to upgrade their plan

h3. Workaround
* Refreshing the page solved the issue
fields.summary: Viewing the code insight report in pull request for more than 3 report return an error to upgrade plan for Paid Workspace
